document.text: The Senatorial Convention Nominates H. D. Flood by AcclamationThe Buckingham and Cumberland Dem ocrats Nominate E. W. Hubard for the House of DelegatesSenator Martin Endorsed. Promptly at the appointed hour, Chairman V. E. Pratt, of the Buck ingham Democracy, called to order the convention of the Eighteenth senatorial district Iu the courthouse ou Monday. The convention organ ized by electing Dr. Pratt chairman and W. W. Haskins secretary. This organization was made permanent. The chair appointed the follow ing committee on credentials Frank Moon, of Buckingham Paul Pettit, f Fluvanna Joel Watkins, of Ap pomattox. The committee reported!he fol lowing delegates present and end- lied to stats in the convention BuckinghamFailed to get the names of these delegates. AppomattoxJoel Watkins, A. II. Clement, James B. Abbitt, II. 8. Coleman, A. B. Thornhill, J. W. Davidson, W. F. Wright. FluvannaA. A. Gray, Paul Pet- dt, C. B. Wood, W. C. White, W. F. Snead. Mr. A. A. Gray, of Fluvanna, then nominated Hon. H. D. Flood to suc ceed himself as Senator from this district, iu a speech which was well received, by the audience, and which elicited much applause, showing plainly that the audience endorsed his eulogistic remarks on Mr. Flood and his record as a representative. Mr. Gray is a pleasant speaker, aud his remarks were timely and highly appreciative. Mr, A. B. Thornhill, of Appomat tox, in a beautiful speech, seconded the nomination of Mr. Flood. He referred to the magnanimity with which Mr. Flood refused the certifi cate of election to Congress in 1896, and presented figures showing that iie received 4,000 more votes than diu Mr. Tucker in 1894, and 6,000 more than did Mr. Quarles in 1898. Mr. Thornhills remarks made a good impressiou, and he was the re cipient of congratulations upon his peech. Messrs. F. C. Moon and Ednt. W. Hubard, ou the part of Bucking ham, made short speeches seconding the nomination. At the conclusion of these speech es Mr. Paul Pettit moved that the nomination be made by acclamation, which was adopted, and the chair appointed Messrs. Gray, Thornhill, and Hubard to iuform Mr. Flood of his nomination, and to present him to the convention. Mr. Flood accepted the nomina tion in a speech of twenty minutes, which aroused much enthusiasm. He assured the peopie of his appie- fiaaou of the honor conferred, and of their endorsement and loyalty, to him and his public acts. He spoke earnestly of the faithful service to the laboring people of Virginia ren dered by Senator Martin, aud of the light he made for him in the Demo cratic caucus six years ago, assuring the Democracy of Virginia that, if- they would lay the mantle of the seuatorship upon Mr. Martin at that time, the Democracy of the Old Do minion would approve their action. Mr. Flood referred to the large ma jority of counties having gone for Senator Martin as proving the truth of his prediction, and said that Mr. Martin would be renominated by a four-fifths majority. At the con clusion of his speech he was pre sented wit-h a bouquet of beautiful flowers. Mr. F. 0. Moon offered the follow ing resolutions, which weie unani mously adopted Resolved, That the course of Hon. T. S. Martin, United States Senator, is fully endorsed and approved and the nomiuee of this convention is in structed to vote for and support Him for re-election to that position. . 2d, That the tiominee of this con vention is instructed to vote for and support Hon. George J. Hundley for re-electiou as Judge of this judicial circuit. Mr. W. W. Haskins said that he was instructed by the Maysville-dis- trict meeting to bring up the ques tion of moving the courthouse aud the nominee was instructed to op pose any movement looking to the removal of the courthouse. The senatorial convention then adjourned, and the house conven tion, composed of delegates from Buckingham and Cumberland, as sembled for the purpose of nomi nating a candidate for the House of Delegates. Dr. Pratt and Mr. Haskins were retained as chairman and secretary, respectively, of the convention.  W. M. Smith, of Cumberland, and F. C. Moon, of Buckingham, were appotiled a committee on creden tials, who reported the following delegates present and entitled to scats in the cony.epjbj.Qn t CumberlandW. if. South, H. D. Woodson. H. K. Adams, E. B. Davis, A. B. Armstrong, and J. W. Adams. BuckinghamWe are nnable to give the names of these delegates. F. C. Moon uommated Hon. E. W. Ilubar.t for delegate to the General Assembly from tjiis district, com posed of Buckingham an,d Cumber land counties, Mr. W. M. Smith, of Cumberland, in a few well chosen remarks, sec onded the nomination. Mr. John W. Adams moved that it be made by acclamation, which was done with a whoop. Sfr. Hubard was informed of his nonuuatiQQ, and was presented to the convention for a speech. Mr. Hubard made onj ?fp t his h.ap-i py speeches, full of logic and rea-! sou. He was severe on independ ents, and promised that the flag of Democracy should not trail in the dust, aud predicted a great victory fojt tjie party at the general election. He appealed ty his hearers with much force io si an cl by fthe nomi nees, saying it was not now afight, of Flood and Hubard, but a fight for the supremacy of Democratic

document.text: STEELE . BURKE Liberty Baptist Church was the scene of a beautiful marriage today. Mr. W. T. Steele and Miss Alice F. Burke were the contracting parties. The church was beautifully decora ted with evergreens, and an arch spanned the church, from which a chandalier, with lighted candles gave the only light for the auditorium. Beneath this arch and chandalier Mr. iSteele and Miss Burke took the marriage vows, using the ring, her pastor, the Rev. Hugh C. Smith, per forming the ceremony in a very im pressive manner. The attendants were as follows Mr. Clinton Steele, brother of the groom, groomsmn, and Miss Vera W. Burke, sister of the bride, maid of honor. The other attendants were Mr. Hallie Burke with Miss Lee Steele Mr. Robert C. Harvey with Miss Jenine Irby Hon. H. D. Flood with Miss M. Elizabeth Burke Dr. James B. Abbitt with Miss Lula Terrell j Mr. Oscar Sho- walter with Miss Roberta Wood Mr. R. L. Burke with Miss Mary Eliza beth Paris j Mr. William Price with Miss Lucy Smith Mr. Tom Steele with Miss Maude Gregory. The ushers were Messers. John Rolfe Horsley, R. Watkins Nowlin, John Overton and Hampton Steele. The little ribbon bearers were Jerry Burke and Jacqueline Atwood Cur tis Taylor and Frances Abbitt Ken dall Hunter and Katie Wooldridge, and James Stanley and Mattie Sears. Before the bridal party entered one verse of O Promise Me was softly sung by Miss Eula Burke, ac companied by Mrs. J. R. Atwood. At the conclusion of the solo followed the strains of Lohrengrins Wedding March. The bridemaids entered from the left wing o f the church near the altar and passed in front of the al tar and down the right aisle. L. Burke, Mrs. James B. Abbitt, Miss Eula May Burke and Miss Vay Abbitt attended the funeral of the late W. B. Irby at Blackstone Tuesda.y John Tavlor was in Richmond on business Tuesday. Effective tomorrow, 24 hourly employees ot Che J. E. Sears Co., Appomattox, will be given a wage ncrese of two and one-half cents per hour. The August meeting of the Appo mattox town council will be held on Friday night, August 1, instead of next Monday night. Chief business at the meeting will be action on the proposals of the Norfolk anu West ern Railway for the additional pro tection at the depot crossing in the to.wn. The installation of a wig-wag light and bell system at this cross ing has been under discussion, al though it is believed that several months would be required before it would be in operation, and then, it would require a railroad expenditure of between 4,000 and 6,000. document.text: MRS. JAMES B. ABBITT Mrs. Vara W. Burke Abbitt, the widow of Dr. James B. Abbitt, died Friday afternoon at 4 oclock, after an illness of several months. She was a former deputy treasurer of Appomattox County. .She was the daughter of the late Richard F. and Alice Sears Burke. For the last twen ty years she had made her home here and was deputy treasurer until her retirement in 1953. She was prominently identified with civic and religious activities both here and in Norfolk where she had previously re sided. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolu tion and the United Daughters of the Confederacy. She was a past president of the Medical Auxiliary of the Norfolk Medical Society. She was an active member of the Liberty Baptist Church here, where she taught a Bible class for many years. Surviving are two daughters, Miss Vay Abbitt and Mrs. C. D. .Staples, both of Bon Air a niece, Mrs. Lee Covington, of Raleigh, N. C. three granddaughters a sister, Mrs. W. T. Steele, of Appomattox two broth ers, Richard L. Burke and Jerry A. Burke, both of Appomattox, and a number of nieces and nephews in addition to Mrs. Covington, whom she reared. Funeral services were held from Liberty Baptist Church at 200 P. M. Sunday, conducted by the pastor, Dr. Carl A. Collins, Jr., assisted by Dr. Twyman Williams. Burial was in Liberty Cemetery. Active pall bearers were Robert A. Sears, Jerry A. Burke, Jr. Richard F. Burke, III R. F. B. Steele, W. T. Steele, Jr. Richard F. Burke, Josh ua Pretlow, and John D. Abbitt.

document.text: MartinMoore. The borne of Mr. W. E. Moore, at Beckham, was the scene of a bemti- iul wedding on Wednesday, May 7, when his attractive and accomplish ed daughter, Miss Maude Annie, be came the wife of Mi. E. B. Martin, u prosperous young farmer of this county. Promptly at 730 p . m . the bridal party, consisting of the bride, bride groom, and following attendants Miss Irvie Moore, of Buena Vista, with Mr, Edgar Martin Miss Mol- lie Martin with Mr. Forest Moore, Miss Faunie Moore with Mr. Robert Babcock, Miss Viola Moss w.th Dr. James B. Abbitt, Miss Edna Burge with Mr. Sidney Martin, Miss Alice Harvey with Mr. James Burge marched into the parlor to the sweet strains of the wedding march, ren dered by Mrs. T. It. Rucker. They were met at the hymeneal altar by Rev. 11. W. Dunkley, the officiating minister. The ceremony was very unique and impressive. Immediate ly after it, the entire party was in vited into the dining-room, where an old-time wedding supper was served. Suffice it to say that the party fared sumptuously. The contracting parties are very popular in the county, and were the recipients of many handsome and useful presents. Among those present fiom a dis tance were Rev. L. J. Moore, of Ma- otaca Miss Irvie Moore, of Buena Vista Dr. aud Mrs. T. It. Rucker of Pedlar Mills.

document.text: Funeral services for Miss May Burke, for many years a puty treasurer of Appomattox County, were held at 2 30 P. M. Tuesday afternoon at the Liberty- Baptist Church, with interment in the Church Cemetery. Services were conducted by the Rev. W. M. Thompson and the Rev. Edgar S. Price. Miss Burke died Sunday in a Lynchburg Hospital. For a number of years, she had been chairman of the Appomattox Chapter, American Red Cross. She was past president of the County Chapter of the Daughters of the Confederacy, member of the D. A R., organizer of the Young DemO cratic Club of Appomattox Coun ty, organizer of the first Girl Scout Troop in the county, instrumental In organizing and conducting health clinics, including T. B. and Crippled Childrens clinics. Surviving are three brothers, K L. and J. A. Burke, both of Appo mattox and William H. Burke, of Floyd two sisters, Mrs. James B Abbitt and Mrs. W. T. Steele, both of Appomattox, and a number of neiees and nephews. _ Active pallbearers were Dr. C. U OBrien, Dr. C. F. James, C. K Hunter, Dr.. H. Y. Spencer, H. C, Pulliam, Judge Joel W. Flood, C W. Smith and R. B. Hudgins.

document.text: This highly connected citizen passed away at his home at Vera Tiesday  in the 71st year of his age, after a ling ering illness of four months. He was a son of the late Col- Geo. Abbitt and is survived by his wife and nine children, Geo. R. Abbitt, Mrs. Sussie Covington. Mrs. Betty OBrien, Mrs. Lillie Casey, Robert Abbitt, W.D,,Col- I yer and A. B. Abbitt and Miss I Laura Abbitt. He leaves also I the following brothers and sis- ItersMrs. W. J. Covington, Mrs Mark Bernard, Mrs- A. P. White, A. B., R. W.. C. W. and Geo. F. Abbitt. Rev. S. P. Tucker, deceaseds pastor conducted funeral service at New Hope Church, where he had worshipped for many years when able to attend. The ser vice was consoling to the bereft family and sweet to his friends. The singing.was especially sweet. F. A. OBrien, Mrs. L E. Smith and Mrs. Bessie James sang sev eral se lections. The casket was I tenderly borne to the church I yard by Geo. R., R. O., W. D.t I A. B, Abitt and Clint Casey, sons and grand-son, where last sad rites were performed by young ladies who covered the grave with beautiful flowers. Raliegh Abbitts passing leaves a memory and frisndship among those who knew and loved him that will not soon die.
